title: the world needs act now
story: The world needs to act now to drag m starving Afghans out of famine hellNo one outside the Taliban and their few friends disputes the need to impose sanctions. But it is in no one’s interest to leave hunger unaddressed, children unvaccinated and girls uneducated.Gordon Brown has warned the world it has just days to save m starving people living in Afghanistan Image: PAopinionByGordon Brown:,  Jan | commentsThere is no such thing as being too late. Preication, penny-pinching and a counterproductive ban on the flow of money that has prevented food supplies getting through, means the world is running out of time to stop a winter of starvation.The lives of  million Afghans are at risk.TV screens are full of scenes of emaciated families, dying children. And not just from famine. There are outbreaks of cholera and polio among children on top of Covid spreading among adults, % unvaccinated. All too slowly the world is waking up to the scale of the disaster. The UN has, thankfully, exempted money for food, health workers and teachers’ salaries from sanctions. But aid is not flowing through. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  The EU has donated million but only one quarter of the money needed for humanitarian aid has come forward. The World Bank has released the same sum but another .bn due to the troubled country remains in its US account. No one outside the Taliban and their few friends disputes the need to impose sanctions. But it is in no one’s interest to leave hunger unaddressed, children unvaccinated and girls uneducated. Previous initiatives have taken weeks and months. Butlives are to be saved three policy changes must be made in days,not hours. First, rich countries who have provided only a quarter of the .bn demanded by UN humanitarian chief Martin Grfith must now release this and ensure the World Bank frees up Afghan money it holds in trust. Second, we must empower the banking system so money can pay for supplies and the salaries of health workers, teachers and public servants who have been unpaid for months. Finally, Britain must call a pledging conference within days to secure the .bn needed to prevent famine. Forty countries joined the US-led coalition to fight the Afghan war. All should now contribute to saving lives amidst this uneasy peace. This weekend, a new Save the Children petition stresses there is not a moment to lose. My friend Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistan girl shot by the Taliban for supporting girls’ education, tells me she will be one of the first to sign.You can too – at savethechildren.org.uk Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON United NationsTalibanSave the ChildrenGordon BrownSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tories must right thing rid
story: Tories must do the right thing and get rid of pathological liar Boris JohnsonBoris Johnson says he implicitly believed the drinks party he claims to have stumbled into was a work event, but he takes citizens for fools, writes Chris McLaughlinBoris Johnson said he believed the party he attended was a work eventopinionByChris McLaughlinPolitical reporter:,  Jan | commentsI’d been thinking of throwing a party. No, seriously, don’t laugh. It was the signicant other’s signicant birthday. Venue checked, band booked, furthest away guests invited, budget swallowed with a big gulp. Then the Covid surge loomed and it was time to call the whole thing off. It was, as everybody sympathetically agreed, the decent thing to do. Didn’t, for some reason, think to call it a “work event” to get round the rules. Guests implicitly agreed that going ahead would be the wrong thing to do. Tough, but nothing compared to the sacrices of others while No partied like a prohibition Speakeasy.Boris Johnson says he “implicitly believed” the drinks party he claims to have stumbled into was a work event, inviting the nation to believe in a Prime Minister who takes citizens for fools. He could have put his foot down when the rules applying to everyone  were being flouted in front of his eyes. Just once, early on, would have done it. A bit of leadership would have got the message across. Instead he sailed on, captaining a Downing Street booze cruise through lockdown restrictions which saw families torn apart, even in the hour of death for their loved ones. The image of the Queen in mournful isolation the day after No staff boozed into the early hours is a powerfully symbolic damnation of the entire scandal. We await the official report from Whitehall sleuth Sue Gray. It was never her civil servant’s job to deliver a killer blow to the Johnson premiership. But her report is a minefield of unexploded bombs – not least those planted by Dominic Cummings – which could trigger the coup de grace on a political le that is already ­effectively over.  Trust, the leblood of a PM’s authority, has been terminated. Slippery Boris may attempt to slither through the Gray dynamite but the long game is up. Critical is whether it can be shown he lied to Parliament. But convincing a pathological liar that they are lying might not be easy. Tory MPs are fearful of this PM leading them into a general election, or even the local elections. But the backfiring defection of Tory Christian Wakeford turned the pork pie revolt stale before it could be served. It threw the crestfallen Big Dog a bone. Bojo got his mojo back and determined to fight on, with a raft of Operation Red Meat announcements to shore up the crumbling edice. Tilting at the BBC and turning the lting of Covid restrictions, and the nation’s health, into a political stunt. Nothing to alleviate the cost-of-living crisis, mind. Chancellor Rishi Sunak must be too busy choosing his furniture for Number . Johnson made fools of his own MPs over humiliating U-turns on free school meals and Tory MP Owen Paterson’s contempt for lobbying rules. If they fail to do the right thing this week they will make fools of themselves and underpin the ongoing damage to British democracy. It might suit Keir Starmer to see the Tories saddled with a laughing stock PM for a little longer. But the only signicant date in the PM’s diary should be his exit. title: tory mp claims sacked muslimness
story: Tory MP claims she was sacked as her Muslimness was raised as an issue in No meetingNusrat Ghani MP for Wealden said she had to considershe wanted to continue being an MP because her faith was left shaken after the interaction. She was sacked as a transport minister in February Nusrat Ghani claimed she was told her Muslimness was raised as an issue during a meeting Image: PAByLucy MiddletonAssistant news editorAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A Tory MP has claimed she was sacked from her ministerial post because of her Muslim faith. Nusrat Ghani, MP for Wealden was a transport minister from January  until February . The married mum became the first female MP to hold her Wealden seat in , winning with a majority of ,. But Ms Ghani considered quitting politics after her interaction with a Government whip who said her Muslimness was raised as an issue at a Downing Street meeting, she told the Sunday Times. The whip added her Muslim woman minister status was making colleagues feel uncomfortable, and questioned her loyalty to the Party. Ms Ghani, now vice-chairwoman of the powerful  Committee of Tory backbenchers told the newspaper: It was like being punched in the stomach. I felt humiliated and powerless. I was told... that there were concerns aposthat I wasnapost loyal to the party as I didnapost do enough to defend the party against Islamophobia allegationsapos. Ms Ghaniaposs claims relate to a meeting back in March . When she raised the issue, she was asked to use the formal complaints procedure but she declined to.Government Chief Whip Mark Spencer took to Twitter to identy himself as the person behind the MPaposs claims. In one now-deleted tweet, he wrote: To ensure other whips are not drawn into this matter, I am identying myself as the person Nusrat Ghani MP has made claims about this evening. These accusations are completely  and I consider them to be defamatory. I have never used those words attributed to me.  The conduct of the whipsapos office has come under intense scrutiny amid accusations they used intimidation and blackmail to pressure MPs seeking to oust Boris Johnson as Prime Minister.William Wragg, the senior Tory who first raised the issue and chairman of the Commons Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee, praised Ghaniaposs courage in speaking out. He said: Nus is very brave to speak out. I was truly appalled to learn of her experience. She shows such strength and integrity supporting others. I am proud to have her as my friend and colleague. We must change things for the better. Wragg will be meeting a Scotland Yard detective in the House of Commons early next week to discuss his own claims. He told The Dailyhe would outline several examples of bullying and intimidation, in some cases involving public money. Fellow Tory MP and former minister Steve Baker also described Ghaniaposs treatment as completely intolerable and suggested her claims be investigated further. He tweeted: I value Nus Ghani as a great colleague and Iaposm appalled. We must get to the bottom of it. Cabinet Minister Nadhim Zahawi and senior Tory MP Tom Tugendhadt also backed Ms Ghani on Twitter, with Mr Zahawi calling for an inquiry on the matter. has contacted No for comment. title: altered taste symptom omicron how
story: Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron  How to tell when your food tastes funnyThe Omicron iant has been found to have symptoms that are dferent from previous Covid strains. Is a change to your sense of taste a sign of Omicron  Here’s what you need to knowOmicron symptoms are more similar to a common cold Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Jan | comments Since it began spreading in late November last year, the Omicron Covid iant has proven to be quite dferent than the previous strains of coronavirus.With symptoms that have been described as being more similar to a common cold, Omicron usually presents as a mild infection. However, the symptoms have been found very dferent from the classic three signs of Covid that we are used to.According to the NHS, the most common signs of coronavirus are a fever, new and continuous cough as well as a loss or change to sense of taste or smell.But is a change to your sense of taste a symptom of Omicron  Hereaposs everything you need to know Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron   A loss or change to your sense of taste or smell means that people who have coronavirus tend not be able to smell or taste anything properly, or things will smell or taste slightly dferent to normal. However, Omicron symptoms have been found to be dferent, with members of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , saying: There is some preliminary evidence emerging of changes in reported symptoms with Omicron infection. In particular, loss of taste or smell seem to be reported less frequently.  Professor Tim Spector of King’s College London, who is leading ZOE symptom appaposs Covid study, also warned that many people may not realise they have Covid. This is because Omicron symptoms are more similar to a common cold and donapost present with a cough, fever, or loss of taste or smell. Though symptoms of the virus have continued to change, there hasnapost been any updates made to the governmentaposs official symptoms list since last spring. How to tellyour sense of taste or smell has changed  An estimated , UK adults have been affected by a change or loss of sense of taste smell, according to Fth Sense, a charity for people affected by smell and taste disorders. The symptom means that food gives off an unpleasant odour or taste, such as rotten meat or chemicals. The specic cause for sensory loss is unknown, but a study published in the Nature Genetics journal suggests that genetics could be play an important role in a person experiencing loss or change in taste or smell after Covid infection. While smell training which involves snfing at least four distinctive smells to retrain the brain is one way to regain sensory loss, most people who experience smell and taste loss because of virus usually regain their sense spontaneously. What are the main symptoms of Omicron   The most common symptoms of Omicron, according to the ZOE Covid study are:Scratchy throat Runny NoseFatigue Body aches and pains SneezingOther reported signs of the iant include headaches, congestion, nausea and vomiting, skin rashes, night sweats, brain fog. The symptoms should last up to five days and be mild for most people. Getting enough rest and over-the-counter medication will help.However,your symptoms get worse and you are concerned, you can get advice from theNHS online , or by calling .Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Omicron iantCoronavirusNHSApps" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: call delay compulsory covid jabs
story: Call to delay compulsory Covid jabs for NHS staff as , remain unvaccinatedThe Government is steaming ahead with the compulsory vaccine plan for all NHS staff, claiming it is the right thing to do to protect patientsNHS staff protested the compulsory vaccine mandate in English cities today Image: NEIL HALL EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments The deadline for compulsory Covid vaccines for NHS staff should be delayed to prevent shortages of frontline workers, according to the Royal College of GPs.Under current plans health workers must have their first jab by February  and be fully vaccinated by April .Those who fail to do so may be unable to continue in their frontline roles. The Department of Health says there are currently no plans to delay the mandate, as it is the right thing to do to protect patients, the BBC reports.It comes after NHS staff staged a protest in opposition to the Governmentaposs clampdown in cities across England, including Manchester, Birmingham and Leeds.  Martin Marshall, chairman of the Royal College of GPs, said the Governmentaposs vaccine mandate was not the right way forward. The vast majority of NHS staff are vaccinated, but , to , workers remain without the jab, Mr Marshall told BBC Radio aposs Today programme. These members of staff account for just  per cent of the entire workforce at some hospital or GP surgeries, he continued. The chairman warned that removing large numbers of employees from the frontline would lead to massive consequences.  If the Government delayed their April  cut off, there would be enough time for staff to have a booster and give space for discussion about whether mandatory vaccinations are suitable, he said.It comes days after Dr Hilary Jones shared he no longer believes it should be mandatory for NHS staff to have the Covid vaccine. Speaking on Good Morning Britain, Hilary explained that forcing healthcare workers to get the vaccine but then ditching self-isolation, even for people who have tested positive for the virus, didnapost make sense. It comes amid reports that , healthcare professionals remain unvaccinated, and are at risk of losing their jobs over the mandatory policy. A guest on the show was called out by Hilary over his comments about there being higher infection rates in vaccinated people, before he went on to call for mandatory jabs to be scrapped. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

news uk-news crazed-rats-seen-terrying-binmen-"Rats scurry away from rubbish as workers attempt to empty binsByAntony ThrowerIsobel Dickinson:,  Jan | commentsWaste collectors have said soaring numbers of rats in the UK now mean they have bash bins before handling them to scare the giant vermin off. In a skin-crawling clip, one worker can be seen nervously approaching the overflowing rubbish before giving the bins a kick. Nothing happens after the first few blows - but eventually the vermin hiding inside eating food which has not been properly disposed of take off scurry out onto drainpipes and across the ground. As many as  rats can be seen in the footage running away. Experts have now said the overfilled bins are leaving workers at risk of being attacked by the rats. Several workers are now even having to tuck their trousers into their socks to stop the vermin running up their legs. Business Waste’s Mark Hall told the Daily Star : “Monday mornings are the worst as bins are overflowing from the weekend with kebabs and tasty food from restaurants.“Our operators come up against rats on a daily basis, but Mondays are especially bad and our teams are genuinely worried about getting bitten.” The rat population in the UK soared during lockdown to around  million. The number is thought to still be on the rise, with many waste collectors off sick due to Covid restrictions, often leaving household rubbish to mount up. Binman Mark Taylor, , from Addingham, added: “When we go to empty a bin on a Monday, there’s a stream of rats running to safety. “It’s really badit’s a food store or a restaurant, and they haven’t secured the lid. We’re clubbing the bins with a big stick, then giving them a couple of minutes to run away. It’s terrying.”Waste Collection companyDivert’s Operations Director Adam Bailey, said: “Once disturbed, the vermin are in a state of panic and run in all directions.“Our teams now go into action with trousers tucked into boots and sleeve cuffs done up tight. But that’s still no guarantee.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TrousersGiant rats" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ex royal cop demands prince
story: Exclusive: Prince Andrew should face royal bullying probe like Meghan Markle, says ex-royal copPaul Page worked in the Royal Protection Command from  until  and alleges complaints he raised during his service were ignored because senior courtiers did not want to create a stirThe pressure is growing on Prince Andrew as efforts to torpedo a lawsuit against him have so far failed Image: Getty ImagesByPatrick HillNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A former royal officer has called for Buckingham Palace to launch a probe into Prince Andrew over bullying claims – just like they did on Meghan. Paul Page, who worked in the Royal Protection Command from  until , alleges he personally made three separate complaints to palace officials. And he claims he is aware of “at least a dozen” other reports made by colleagues. Mr Page, whose revelations this week sparked a string of complaints about the prince, said: “Buckingham Palace launched a bullying investigation against Meghan last year after she was accused of wrongdoing. “If it’s a fair organisation that looks after its staff, an investigation should be started to confirm whether or not Andrew is guilty of being a bully and of intimidating staff.”  He alleges complaints he raised during his service were ignored because senior courtiers did not want to create a stir. Mr Page told the Sunday Mirror: “The Palace have a problem because there are instances and evidence of Prince Andrew being overbearing and verbally abusive.” He said in an ITV documentary this week that Andrew would “shout and scream”his collection of toy bears on his bed were not placed in exact positions by maids. That prompted the prince’s former maid Charlotte Briggs, , to come forward with allegations. She accused Andrew, then in his s, of foul-mouthed rants and ludicrous demands. They included making her run up four flights of stairs to close his curtains while, she says, he was right next to them.  She also told of being in tears and of hiding to avoid the “bad-tempered” and “entitled” royal. Diplomat Simon Wilson, who hosted the duke in Bahrain, previously claimed the “rude” and “boorish” prince had “childish obsessions” and was nicknamed HBH by staff – for His Buffoon Highness. Former maid Janette McGowan, , claimed she had to check a Polaroid of  teddy bears on Andrew’s bed and lay them out in exact positions to avoid him becoming angry. Mr Page claimed there “must have been at least a dozen complaints” about bullying in the time he was there. He alleged: “It was well known in the palace, but no investigation was conducted by the royal household.”  Mr Page claimed a colleague had been called a “fat lardy-a***d c***” by the prince after stopping a woman at the gates who had not been listed as an invited guest. He said: “Even the woman went bright red and said, ‘I’m really sorry’. Another time a woman got locked in and he came down f-ing and blinding and ranting.” Andrew,  – ninth in line to the throne – is facing calls to be evicted from -room Royal Lodge after being told to stop using his HRH title and stripped of his military titles and charitable affiliations.  He is fighting sex assault claims in the US in a civil suit by Virginia Giuffre, the alleged sex slave of his former pal Jeffrey Epstein. He vehemently denies the claims. Mr Page lost his job when he was convicted over a £million investment fraud in . The Palace and a spokesman for Prince Andrew declined to comment. title: farmers slam mcdonalds after being
story: Farmers slam McDonalds after being forced to take off boots before enteringThe group said they were "shocked" when an employee for the fast food chain - which prides itself on sourcing produce from British farms - reportedly told them they had to remove their boots before eatingA group of teen farmers were shocked when they were told to remove their boots before entering a McDonalds in Crewe Image: MEN MEDIAByJosh PenningtonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A group of teen farmers say they were stunned when McDonaldaposs staff reportedly refused to serve them unless they took off their work boots - which they say were clean.The farming students said they were hungry and looking forward to a burger and fries at the Crewe branch of McDonaldaposs last Monday, when staff are said to have stopped them at the door.They were shocked when an employee for the fast food chain - which prides itself on sourcing produce from British farms - reportedly told them they had to remove their boots before eating, Cheshire Live reports.A member of staff insisted so the teens left their footwear outside the front door, they said. The Reaseheath Agricultural College students claim they saw local builders were allowed in for a meal while wearing filthy boots. Teen farmer Jamie Goode, , from Holmes Chapel, said: “We were shocked when they wouldn’t let us in. We just laughed at them. “This lady was standing there and said that before we could enter, we had to take our boots off.  All our boots were clean and certainly not mucky but they insisted they wouldnapost let us in unless we took them off. There were a lot of workmen going in with their boots on, and theirs were filthy. Jamie believes someone from his college may have told restaurant staff to stop students entering with their boots on. He said: When we asked why [we couldnapost go in], they said Reaseheath [college] said we should be told to take our boots off. “But when we got back, the college said they knew nothing about such an instruction. They said it was probably a health and safety issue to ask to take our boots off, but this is not rightthey are allowing the building trade inside with their boots. He added: “We don’t even understand how they knew that we were from the college – we didn’t have our ID badges on or anything. A spokesperson from McDonaldaposs said: “We are proud supporters of British and Irish agriculture and work with over , farmers across the UK and Ireland. We have a strong relationship with the local Agricultural college and we have an agreement in place to ensure students that visit our restaurant remove their wellington boots, to ensure the restaurant maintains the high standards that all our customers expect. We greatly appreciate the cooperation of the college and students, and look forward to continuing to welcome them to our restaurant in the future.” The Mirror has contacted McDonaldaposs for further comment. title: four schoolgirls aged 13 17
story: Four schoolgirls aged  to  sexually assaulted in  month as police hunt attackerThe four girls were all targeted in Greenwich, south east London, between December  and January  and police searching for the attacker have released a photo of someone they want to talk toPolice have released a photo of a man they want to speak to in relation to the assaults Image: Met PoliceBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Police hunting a man after four schoolgirls were sexually assaulted have released a photo of a person they want to speak to. The victims, aged between  and , were all targeted in Greenwich, south east London, inside a month.The force launched an urgent hunt after the youngsters all came forward to report the attacks. Three of the assaults took place within just six days of each other in the middle of January, the Met say. Detectives believe the offences may be linked and have asked anyone with information to come forward.  The first incident took place on December  when a -year-old child was followed after getting off a bus in on Hoveton Road. The man sexually touched her before running away when the victim screamed, police say. Three more attacks took place in mid-January. A police statement added: On Wednesday,  January, a -year-old girl was walking down Poplar Place, SE when she was approached by a man asking for directions. He pushed her against a fence and sexually touched her before she screamed and was able to run away.  On Thursday,  January, a -year-old girl was followed off the  bus by a man at Artillery Place, SE. He followed her into a nearby property and grabbed the back of her leg, causing her to fall. As she was on the floor he sexually touched her and ran from the scene when the victim shouted for help. On Tuesday,  January, a -year-old girl was walking down Kentlea Road, SE, when she was approached by a man who asked for directions. As she attempted to walk away, he sexually touched her before she was able to escape. DS James Robinson, who is leading the investigation, has asked anyone with information to make themselves known. “We know these incidents will cause concern within the community and we are doing all we can to identy the person responsible, he said. “We are also asking for your help –you recognise the man in this image or have any information that could assist us, no matter how small, then contact us as soon as possible.” Anyone with information should call  with CAD reference  JAN or Crimestoppers  per cent anonymously on   . title: granddad 63 who didnt want
story: Granddad, , who didnt want to bother GP ends up fighting for le against sepsisMartin Kew was ill for around a week before he finally had to call  who sent an ambulance in time to save his le as he struggled to breatheMartin Kew, , had felt ill for around a week in August  with cold symptoms which turned out to be sepsis Image: BPM MEDIAByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | comments A grandfather who ‘did not like to be any trouble’ ended up on a ventilator fighting for his le with sepsis.Martin Kew, , had felt ill for around a week in August  with cold symptoms and promised his worried daughter to talk to his GP during a routine appointment a week later. Before he could however, his condition rapidly got worse and he struggled to catch his breath. He managed to call  who recognised his symptoms, including blotchy skin, being sleepier than normal and having breathing dficulty as sepsis and dispatched an ambulance. The crew arrived just in time as Martin was unresponsive. Son-in-law Craig Cotterill said: “The ITU staff at Chesterfield Royal have been nothing short of incredible, he wasn’t treated like just a patient, but as an actual person, someone’s dad, grandad and partner.  The staff at Wythenshawe have also been fantastic, they sought approval for his young granddaughter to visit on Christmas Day, and bought him a Christmas gt.We would like to say a huge thank you to both hospitals, we are so very grateful to them for literally saving Martinaposs le and for all the kindness and compassion they have shown him and us throughout the past six months.After being taken to hospital Martin was admitted to the intensive therapy unitat Chesterfield Royal Hospital where he remained on a ventilator for almost three months. He was eventually transferred to Wythenshawe hospital which specialises in long-term ventilation patients and has recently managed to come off the ventilator he has been dependent on since August. Craig and his we Debbie decided to start a fundraiser to help raise some funds for any equipment for Martin. Any extra cash will be donated to transforming the Intensive Therapy Unit garden at Chesterfield Royal Hospital, at Martinaposs request. Craig added: “It would be so lovely for the ITU staff and patients to have their own little haven in that space as I know just how much it helped Martinaposs mental health and positive attitude, and helped keep his fighting spirit alive which is why he’s doing so well now. news uk-news greggs-secrets-revealed-former-employee-"Greggs employee shows piles of food thrown away dailyByChristian BrayfordGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPeople may love the idea of free sausage and an endless supply of steak bakes. But the reality of working for a high street bakery can be quite dferent. Christian Brayford worked at Greggs and revealed the secrets of the bakery and what staff have to deal with ion a daily basis. And he says the free food and drinks which come as a perk of the job were not worth the time, effort and aposextremely dficultapos circumstances workers faced. GrimsbyLive reports the realities of working at the High Street bakery where he worked at multiple locations. Hereaposs what he had to sayI worked at Greggs what feels like a millennium ago. In fact, it was only back in January  but world events and a global pandemic have caused time to seemingly stop in its wake.I really enjoyed the food - I still do now. I often go to the Greggs on Old Brumby Street for a pasty treat .Whenever Iaposm in Grimsby, Iaposll always nip in to the Victoria Street store for a pink jammie doughnut.I used to work at Greggs in Tadcaster, just off the A heading to York. At the time, I was a sht leader so I was in charge of cash handling, staff management, dealing with complaints, ordering stock, and banking at the end of the day.  The working hours could be extremely demanding. You had to be there at am on some shts, and usually you wouldnapost leave until after pm or later. And when you arrived for work, it was absolutely freezing. It was probably colder outside the shop than it was in it - without the exaggeration. This was back in January so in the early hours of the morning it was particularly icy and brisk. You werenapost allowed to wear a jumper either - you were provided with a Greggs hat, Greggs t-shirt, a kitchen apron and a hair net .  Breakfast is a huge part of Greggs and why people love it so much. The egg, sausage and omelette roll was always a firm favourite of mine - along with ketchup. At the start of the sht, youaposd have to put the delivery away. I found it odd that Greggs has two deliveries in a day - one in the very early hours of the morning and one in the afternoon. But this was dependant on the storeaposs location. Our store used to have a delivery at around am or am in the morning.  This was when youaposd have a delivery of all your sweet treats such as triple chocolate doughnuts, jam heart biscuits, Belgian buns and much more. We would spend time on the delivery and preparing for breakfast - ensuring enough trays of bacon, sausage and omelette were prepared for the busiest part of the day. And it was also the time that the bulk of sandwiches were made. So whether you like a roast chicken and bacon club sandwich, a tuna crunch baguette, or a chargrill chicken oval bite, this was the prime time that they were made. There was a specic guide, or cooking matrix, which had to be followed to incredible detail when preparing a sandwich. It came down to the right amount of sauce, the right amount of vegetable and the right amount of protein or meat. If you went over by the slightest margin, youaposd have to make the sandwich again. This is not to say that sandwiches werenapost made throughout the day because they were, whatever was running short or low, weaposd always have someone in the back preparing them from fresh.  Mostly all the items sold in Greggs are made in one of its factories, which are then transported to its stores to be refrigerated or to be kept frozen. All the pasties, cookies, sausages, croissants, pain au chocolates were frozen before cooking. The way to tell the dference with a Greggs pasty is by the design and shapes on its surface. For instance, a corned beef pasty has horizontal little lines across its surface. It never took long to cook them as the cookers were fantastically hot and very large to pack in almost everything you needed for the day. Drinks were always a nightmare, it would take what felt like an hour to prepare one when you had a queue so long and people getting very agitated for a sausage roll. And you always used to see the same people every day. That was always nice as you got to connect with people and have a bit of a chat and a laugh. But there were also times when it wasnapost great.  Especially when you had a man from Plymouth shouting in your face because you didnapost have any milk chocolate cookies available or when Peter from York couldnapost use a loyalty stamp that was out of date. I strongly sympathise and understand all customer service workers who go through similar things - but in dferent situations and environments - on a daily basis. It certainly made it harder to motivate yourself to get up in the morning. And the close down was always a nightmare. We would practice hygiene and cleaning throughout the day on a aposclean as you go basisapos but the shear volume of closing down was insane. It usually took over an hour to record the dayaposs banking, ensure all food beyond its use by date had been thrown away, and to clean the entire place from top to bottom. I know it doesnapost sound a lot, but it certainly felt like it after a demoralising sht of dealing with complaints, rudeness and a high demand for a cheese bake. But one of the glorious delights at the end of the day was being able to take food home. Youaposd be really surprised at how much food was wasted. It was literally a tonne of pure sausage rolls and baguettes and sweets. But it was great to decide which food you wanted to take home. Sometimes Iaposd walk out of the building with about four of five bags of food. It was great to see my familyaposs face when I brought them something back. My time at Greggs was very short lived, the first lockdown in March  put an end to my time there. When I was asked to go back in August , I kindly declined the offer and handed in my notice. So looking back at it now, was it all really worth it  The kindest answer is no. Even by the time the first lockdown was imposed, I felt like a walking zombie. The long hours were particularly draining. Sometimes youaposd be working five days on sht patterns of  hour days which can be demanding. The pay was hovering very close to the national minimum wage of around £. at the time. So you canapost really complain and grumble as it was a job. The free food at the end of the day was amazing - evenit impacted my waist line. But what really tipped me over the edge was the rudeness of customers. And I still see the similar kind of rudeness today but in a dferent shop. People can be so thoughtless and insensitive as to how their actions might be devastating or impact another person. The abuse was unjustied and uncalled for. But the saying goesthere isnapost a reason to complain, someone will find a reason too. I loved the food, but I donapost think the experience of working in a Greggs was all it is cracked up to be. title: holidaymakers joy covid tests return
story: Holidaymakers joy as Covid tests onto UK may be scrapped in daysPassengers taking rapid lateral flow tests on arrival home from holidays could be ditched from as early as Monday amid planned changes to travellingThe tests could be ditched from next week amid planned changes to the travel industry Image: Getty ImagesByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | commentsHaving to take Covid tests after ing to the UK may be scrapped as early as Monday amid changes being discussed. Currently, double jabbed travellers have to take rapid lateral flow tests once they arrive home, adding extra expense to breaks away.But in a boost to the travel industry, as well as people suffering January blues, the tests could be ditched from next week, making it easier to take holidays, reports claim.The Cabinet’s “Covid O” committee is also set to discuss whether being fully vaccinated means having two jabs, or also having the booster. There are also discussions being held to make passenger locator forms easier to use. It comes as a study published on Friday said testing rules should be a ‘thing of the past’ for jabbed passengers.  Conducted by specialist consultants Oxera and Edge Health, the research shows Governments cannot react quickly enough to be effective against new iants of Covid. As a result, travel restrictions made in response to new discoveries do not help limit the spread, they argue.Airlines UK CEO Tim Alderslade said: “Testing restrictions for the fully vaccinated make no sense at all given the delay in Governments being able to detect and act on the arrival of a new iant, as we saw with Omicron. “This is something the World Health Organisation themselves have admitted. Not only do they fail to suppress the international spread of iants, they place a disproportionate burden on the travel sector and those that rely on the connectivity aviation provides. “We need to be smarter in how we deal with future iants rather than resorting to blanket but wholly ineffective measures. Otherwise we will never be able to truly say we are living with Covid.”Airlines UK and MAG, which owns Manchester, London Stansted and East Midlands airports, are calling on Ministers to not only remove all remaining restrictions on international travel, but to reconsider their role in reacting to future iants of coronavirus. Brits looking to book holidays have plenty of options, with a number of countries open to UK holidaymakers including Greece, Portugal and Cyprus.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON World Health OrganisationCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how britains most notorious cold
story: How Britain’s most notorious Cold War spy betrayed lelong friend who never recoveredThe relationship between Nicholas Elliott and Kim Philby is the focus of new star studded drama A Spy Among Friends, with Damian Lewis and Guy Pearce playing the key rolesDamian Lewis as Nicholas Elliott and Guy Pearce as Kim PhilbyByLaura Connor:,  Jan | commentsChuckling over rude jokes in a dimly lit Mayfair pub, Nicholas Elliott loved the company of his friend and fellow MI agent – and trusted him implicitly. When whispers broke that there was a traitor in the ranks, Elliott leapt to the defence of his pal. But this was no ordinary friendship. And his pal was playing him all along – as he did so many others. The chum  Kim Philby. Britain’s most notorious Cold War spy, responsible for the deaths of countless Western colleagues due to his leaked intelligence. Double-agent Philby had worked for the communists since he was . He used his position at MI, where he rose through the ranks, to benefit the former Soviet Union at the expense of Britain. Finally, after Elliott himself forced the truth in , Philby fled to join his KGB paymasters in Moscow. The womaniser would marry there – for the fourth time to Rufina Pukhova – and his adopted country even dedicated a stamp to him. Elliott was shattered and never recovered from his ally’s betrayal of Britain and their friendship. Now the relationship is the focus of new TV drama A Spy Among Friends, starring Damian Lewis as Elliott and Guy Pearce as the deceitful Philby. They have been filming in Romania and London. Director Nick Murphy said: “How could I resist the opportunity to dramatise the true story of spies and lelong friends, one of whom was betraying the other all along  “A friendship that resulted in the gutting of British and American intelligence at the height of the Cold War and shaped the field of play for the dangerous game against Russia we’re still trying to win today.” Philby’s biographer James Hanning said public schoolboys Elliott and Philby were from the same cloth. Friends for  years, they had a shared love for cricket and long lunches with a pink gin tipple.  Hanning said: “They had been in MI together for a long time. “Elliott was an old-school gent – his father was the headmaster of Eton, he was very straight, conventional and amusing. He was keen on schoolboy jokes – him and Philby did a lot of drinking and giggling and gossiping over dirty jokes. “They were very close. Elliott was younger than Philby and his protege in the war. He looked up to him. I am not sure he ever got over the embarrassment and shame of his deception. “Philby rang rings around him.” Damian Lewis, , says the drama is “an up-close look at friendship, a friendship blinded by love, class and membership to the right clubs and ended in betrayal and the deaths of thousands”. Pearce, , said he has always “been fascinated by the intriguing MI history”. And few spy tales get more intriguing than this. By the end of World War Two, Philby – codenamed “Sonny” by the Soviets – was head of counter-espionage operations for MI, responsible for combating Soviet subversion in Western Europe. In  he went to Washington as chief MI officer.  In secret, he revealed Allied intelligence to the USSR that the UK and US were planning to send units into communist-leaning Albania. The Americans grew increasingly suspicious, especially when traitors Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean fled to the USSR in  – after Philby tipped them off the net was closing in. The incident forced Philby’s resignation. He, Burgess and Maclean were part of the Cambridge Five spy ring – university contemporaries from the s. But MI spy-catchers failed to pin anything on Philby. Five years on, he landed a job as a journalist in Beirut and resumed his career as a Soviet spy. As MI gathered mounting evidence, a chastened Elliott volunteered to go to Beirut to confront the traitor himself. Their famous encounter in January  still remains shrouded in mystery. And although Elliott did get a written confession from his old pal, it was considered useless. Biographer Hanning said: “Elliott told his colleagues thatPhilby had any sense of shame and decency, the person he owed was him. Soanyone could get Philby to confess, it was him. It was quite emotional. Elliott said, ‘My God, I respected you, I hope you have the decency to know how much I hate you’.  “He was incredibly angry. He offered him an immunity dealPhilby would tell him who  was recruited. “He felt embarrassed in the eyes of the bosses and he thought he was most likely to get a deal out of him.” But Philby fled days later, with some suggesting MI wanted him to run to avoid a humiliating trial in the UK. According to Hanning’s book Love and Deception: Philby in Beirut, Elliott wrote a full account of his Lebanese trip, which was vetted by the intelligence services and never published.  Elliott’s son Mark confirmed: “Kim was as close a friend as my father ever had. “My father told me he had written an autobiography. He had to get approval from ‘The Office’ for its publication. This they would not give.” Elliott bitterly felt the betrayal until his death at the age of  in . As Philby reached the rank of colonel in the KGB in Russia – where he lived until his death at  in  – UK intelligence services gradually realised the names he had given Elliott were duds. Hanning believed Philby never had any true respect for his friend, deliberately calling him “Nick” to his we Eleanor, knowing he hated the abbreviation. Hanning said: “Philby outwitted him at every turn and the confession was worthless in the end. They never questioned Philby again. They never got the chance. Philby got away. I am not sure Elliott ever got over that.” A Spy Among Friends is expected to air on Britbox in the autumn. story: Exclusive: MP demands inquiry into benefits system that drives veterans to suicide and self-harmThe service was set up to assess compensation and pension claims but last week the Sunday People revealed k wounded serving or former members of the armed forces had claims rejectedOwen Thompson branded the treatment of wounded troops a disgrace Image: PABySean Rayment:,  Jan | commentsAn MP is demanding a public inquiry into the Government’s leline for wounded troops.Owen Thompson’s call comes after scores of personnel told the Sunday People the Ministry of Defence ’s Veterans UK service was unfit for purpose.We told last week how delays in providing support had led some to take their lives or self-harm. And we uncovered shocking figures showing more than , wounded serving or former members of the armed forces have had claims for compensation rejected. SNP MP Mr Thompson branded their treatment a “disgrace” saying: “Injured veterans need support from the Government, not a stressful fight for justice.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  “It’s time for a root-and branch inquiry to tackle these issues, fix the system and make sure all veterans get the respect and support they deserve and require. “UK Veterans assessors seem to regularly reject applications, despite medical reports provided.” Veterans minister Leo Docherty said that: “We take the wellbeing of all those who have served extremely seriously.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Ministry of DefencePensionsPublic inquirySunday PeopleArmed forcesSoldiers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prince andrew could patronages restored
story: Prince Andrew could have patronages restoredhe wins case in Queens letimeThe Queen could restore Prince Andrews royal patronageshe beats a civil case launched by Jeffrey Epsteins teen sex slave Virginia Giuffre within the monarchs letimePrince Andrew could have his royal patronages restored by the Queenhe beats his civil case in her letime, its claimed Image: Getty ImagesByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Jan Prince Andrew could have his royal patronages restoredhe wins his legal case while the Queen is still alive, according to an insider. The Duke of York faces a civil trial in the US after a judge rejected his lawyersapos bid to block a sex abuse case launched by Virginia Giuffre. Ms Gufre claims Jeffrey Epstein forced her to have sex with the royal on three occasions when she was just . Andrew vehemently denies the claims. The Queen stripped her son of his military affiliations and royal patronages earlier this month in a decisive response to the scandal. He is also no longer allowed to use his HRHtitle in any official capacity.  However, a source close to Andrew has reportedly now claimed that his royal patronages could be restoredhe wins his civil case while the Queen is alive. They told The Times: I thinkthe Queen is still alive and his name is cleared I would say that at that point what reason would there be for him to be barred from taking part in royal duties. The associate believes Andrew is less likely to have his titles and patronages restoredhe is cleared when Charles is king. They added: It’s a dferent decision-maker and dferent people influencing him and therefore it’s slightly less predictable.  I think his brother is a very reasonable and intelligent person and I’m sure he will do what’s right for the royal family and for the country.” The source said they thought there was no reason Andrew could not use HRH and his military titles againhe is cleared in court. The associate believes Andrew will want to fight the claims in court to aposclear his nameapos, instead of reaching a settlement with Ms Giuffre. But Royal expert Ingrid Seward, who edits Majesty magazine, questioned aposwhat on earthapos Andrew would dohe makes ato public le.  It comes after amid an ongoing row over Prince Andrewaposs publicly-funded police protection. The Duke of York could be stripped of his bodyguards as early as next month, according to reports.His politan Police and Home Office security detail is said to be under review.The taxpayer currently pays for his police protection at an estimated cost of between £million and £million a year.However, many have argued the royal should lose his publicly-funded security as Prince Harry was stripped of his when he stepped down as a senior royal.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The Royal and VIP Executive Committee is now said to be reviewing Andrewaposs protection, sources told the Daily Mail. One insider said: Although no-one will comment on it publicly, this is an issue that is now actively being discussed by the Metaposs Royal and VIP Executive Committee. aposThe situationis awkward and may prompt a decision sooner rather than later. title: prince andrews cuddly toy collection
story: Prince Andrews cuddly toy collection would make most women run a mileRachael Bletchly says an insider has revealed that Prince Andrew still sleeps with a little gang of furry friends, with staff keeping a list of instructions on where to place the toysAn insider claimed Prince Andrew sleeps with some cuddly toys Image: Getty ImagesopinionByRachael Bletchly:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan The Duke of York and his ex-we Fergie are apparently planning to remarry. Which is just as well as he’s NEVER going to find a new squeeze after the latest bedroom revelations. Not the sex abuse ones which, of course, Prince Andrew vehemently denies and still has a chance to defend himself in a US legal action. But in the court of public opinion he has been well and truly stuffed by the details of his cuddly toy fetish.A former servant has claimed that ­after his orce from Fergie in  Andrew kept a ­collection of  teddies and ­other ­animals lined up with ­military precision on his Buckingham Palace bed.Every night the maid had to move the heir bear bunch to set positions around the room so that they “looked pretty”. The small ones dressed in sailor unorms were ranked by size order in an unused fireplace and his two favourite bears sat on ickle thrones on either side of the bed. Then, in the morning, she had to put them all back again, using a diagram to ensure they were correctly positioned. Becauseso much as a whisker was out of place the Queen’s favourite son would scweam and scweam like a toddler having a tantrum.This all sounded so bizarre that I ­wonderedAndrew was going through some sort of post-orce breakdown at the time – especially as the maid says he also kept Fergie’s make-up on his dressing table and her wedding gown in the wardrobe. But another insider has claimed that Andrew STILL sleeps with a little gang of furry friends. And staff also keep a list of instructions showing where Heart-Holding Teddy sits and how Grey Hippo should be placed on the bed on top of a special green blankie.Crikey. I know that ­millions of grown men still cherish a childhood teddy. But Andrew’s menagerie would make most women run a mile. Because we all know there is something deeply dodgy about a bloke who keeps piles of soft toys on his bed. It suggests that he still sucks his thumb, likes wearing nappies and will want to call you Mummy while you dust his bottom with talcum powder. But I’m sure loyal Sarah is well used to Andy’s ‘Toy Story’ fantasies by now. So we can only hope that they tie the knot soon – and buzz off to infinity and beyond.Read MoreRead MoreFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Alex FergusonPrince HarryPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkBuckingham PalaceMarriageRoyal FamilyToysSunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-andrew-slept-multiple-teddy-"Prince Andrew: Former royal bodyguard discusses teddiesByLucy MiddletonAssistant news editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew slept with multiple teddy bears in his bed even during his marriage to Sarah Ferguson, a royal biographer has revealed. The Duke of York was married to Fergie for  years - and during that time still slept with around a dozen teddy bears on his bed, royal expert Ingrid Seward claimed. She recalled noticing the toys while visiting Fergie at Buckingham Palace in  to assist with the biography she was writing.The revelation comes after former Palace maid Charlotte Briggs revealed how she had to spend a whole day learning how the Duke liked the soft toys displayed on his bed during the s.Andrew and Fergie were married from  to , and share daughters Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie together.  Remembering the teddies during her visit, Ingrid said she assumed they belonged to the Duchess, and were from her childhood.She told The Sun : I said to her, ‘Oh Fergie, you haven’t still got your old teddies have you  And she said, ‘No they are all Andrew’s’. We found it very funny and fell about laughing.” Former Palace maid Charlotte worked for the Royal Family in the mid-s, and claimed staff were given a diagram on how to place Andrewaposs  cuddly toys around his room. She said: “As soon as I got the job, I was told about the teddies and it was drilled into me how he wanted them. “I even had a day’s training. Everything had to be just right. It was so peculiar.” She added: “But he absolutely loved the ­teddies and was very clear about how he wanted them arranged.”  Charlotte, who was  at the time, said the biggest teddies were put at the back and the rest were in descending order of size to the smallest at the front. She claimed the Princeaposs two favourite teddies were placed on mahogany thrones at his bedside. She further added that the vast majority of teddies were dressed as sailors, in unorms and caps, and came from all over the world. Charlotte even claimed Andrew frequently lost his temper with the staff, especiallyit involved his cuddly toys.  She added: It took me half an hour to arrange them — most bizarre thing to be paid for. Andrew lives with ex-we Fergie at the Royal Lodge in Windsor, but a suite of rooms was kept for him at the Palace for overnight stays. It is understood his Palace bedroom has been packed up and his teddy collection has been scaled back.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Alex FergusonSarah FergusonPrincess BeatricePrince Andrew, Duke of YorkBuckingham PalaceMarriageRoyal FamilyToysBears" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-harry-losing-role-final-"William and Harry: Tensions existed before arrival of MeghanByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPrince Harry would face no going back to his former royal leheaposs axed as a Counsellor of State, itaposs claimed.The Duke of Sussex, , is one of four Counsellors of States, alongside Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince Andrew. These royals, as the next four people in the line of succession who are over the age of , would undertake The Queenaposs official duties as Sovereign on a temporary basis due to illness or absence abroad.But there are questions whether Harry is eligible as he now lives, for the most part, in the US with we Meghan Markle. The pair stepped back as senior members of the royal family in .And it has now been claimed this would be a catastrophic blow for Harry, who it emerged last year has relinquished his royal patronages.Being removed, by parliament no less, as a Counsellor of State would really be the nail in Harry’s coffin of his former le as a frontline member of the royal family, a source told the Daily Mail. If the Queen does take steps to have this situation remedied and Harry is axed, there really is no going back. All of these decisions – the military titles, the HRHs in abeyance – could theoretically be reversed. However, having parliament take formal action to remove them as Counsellors of State is in another league entirely.  The prince, who married Meghan in May  and since had two children with the former actress, left his royal titles in the UK two years ago.Itaposs still unclearHarry and Meghan, , will join the Queen and the rest of the family for Prince Philipaposs memorial to be held on an as yet unspecied date.It comes as the Sussexes have raised concerns over their security back in the UK, with Harry claiming an offer to pay for his own was previously refused. In , the Queenaposs father King George VI created the Regency Act which decided the Counsellors of States in their current model. Counsellors of State can attend Privy Council meetings, sign routine documents and receive the credentials of new ambassadors to the United Kingdom. news uk-news queen-couldnt-say-no-humiliating-"Royals take part in Its A Royal Knockout TournamentByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe Queenaposs motto that you need to be seen to be believed is something all the royal family live by, so theyaposre always keen to be involved in as many projects as possible. They attend royal engagements and travel the world on tours, meeting thousands of people every year. But sometimes, when a royal is starting to fall out of favour, they may do other bits and bobs in a bid to win fans over - with dfering levels of success. In June , Prince Edward, who organised the event, Princess Anne, Prince Andrew and Fergie went head-to-head in a special episode of Itaposs a Royal Knockout. Each royal had a team, which was representing a dferent charity, made up of celebrities, including the late Meat Loaf, who competed in a number of dferent events.However, it didnapost go quite as they hoped and has since been described as a disaster from start to finish and one of the biggest c***-ups in the royal familyaposs history. Royal expert Ben Pimlott claims the Queen didnapost like the idea at all and all of her staff believed it would be a mistake. An insider told him: [The Queen] was against it, but one of her faults is that she canapost say no. Recalling the show on Channel aposs Fergie Vs Diana:Royal Wives at War, royal expert Jennie Bond said: Itaposs a Royal Knockout will go down in royal history as one of the biggest c**k-ups of all time I think. It was a disaster from beginning to end, it was absolutely humiliating. Sarah with her usual gusto entered into it, andshe gets into something she does it with bells on. However not all of the royal family took up the offer of taking part.  Speaking on the documentary, the Daily Mailaposs Richard Kay said: Diana famously didnapost take part, neither did Charles. He thought it was something that was beneath them. In a way, itaposs kind of unfair, Fergie took a lot of the blame, almost the scapegoat. Her behaviour was being commented on and I think, then, is when Diana came into her own. The show, which was filmed at Alton Towers, was hosted by Stuart Hall, Les Dawson and Su Pollard. Paul Daniels acted as the chief referee. Princess Anneaposs red team, raising cash for Save the Children, included Tom Jones, Clf Richard, actress Jenny Agutter, and athlete Deborah Flintoff. Fergie was joined by Michael Brandon, Ben Cross and Jane Seymour, while Prince Andrewaposs World Wildle Team included Gary Lineker, Margot Kidder, Rhys Jones and John Travolta. Meat Loaf, who passed away this week, also took part. Prince Edward was in charge of the yellow team, raising cash for the Duke of Edinburgh Scheme. Among the celebs on his team were John Cleese, Eddie Grant, Peter Blake and Christopher Reeve. More than million people turned into watch it, making it the fourth most watched show of the year. However, it wasnapost all bad news as they at least managed to raise £.m for their chosen charities. title: teen girl could internally decapitated
story: Exclusive: Teen girl could be internally decapitated at any time due to walking death sentenceAllesha Barnfield, from Highfields, South Yorkshire, could become paralysed or internally decapitated at any moment, due to a rare condition which is pulling her brain into her spinal canalAllesha and her boyfriend Kieran, who she is rarely able to see because or her crippling condition Image: CollectByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA teenager who feels like a ‘walking death sentence’ is desperately fighting for brain surgery to stop a rare condition internally aposdecapitatingapos her.Allesha Barnfield, , started looking for answers three years ago, when her daily headaches became so crippling that she was bed bound and couldn’t bear noise or light. The former college student, from Highfields, South Yorkshire, had been studying law with dreams of going to university and becoming a lawyer - but they were crushed overnight when she was diagnosed with Chiari Malformation.The condition, which causes ligaments in the spine to be tense and tighter than usual, sees the brain tissue of its victims pulled into their spinal cord and can eventually lead to paralysis. It can lead to so-called internal decapitation, when the ligaments that connect the skull to the spine are severed. Petried by the prognosis, Allesha has opted not to be told by doctors how long she has before this happens. Have you got an inspiring story to tell  Email webnews@mirror She said: “This condition has ruined my le. I had dreams of becoming a lawyer and going to university but I can’t go anymore. “I spend every day confined in my room in complete darkness because I can’t bear the light. “I find the smallest noises excruciatingly painful, even when someone is talking to me I have to ask them to whisper. “When they told me what would eventually happen to me I just broke down. “I asked them not to tell me how long I had based on my scans because I just don’t think I can handle knowing. I feel like a walking death sentence.”Allesha, who lives with her sister and was diagnosed by an NHS doctor in September , is not eligible for surgery on the health service.The teen took matters into her own hands when she claimed that teachers and doctors refused to accept she was really suffering.  Allesha said: “It wasnapost until  that I started getting these horrible headaches. “I have had migraines before but I knew that these weren’t migraines because I could physically feel the back of my head shocking me. “It started out as once a week but then it got to the point where it was everyday, all day. “I took myself to the doctors and I was desperately trying to get people to believe me and listen to me. “I felt like I was being treated like a child, which I know I am but I also know my own body “Eventually one GP finally listened to me and I was referred for an MRI and to a neurosurgeon. “He told me I had Chiari Malformation but never really explained what it was or what that meant.” After researching Chiari Malformation, Allesha discovered a clinic in Barcelona who are offering a new kind of surgery which promises to eliminate the condition for its victims altogether. In the UK, surgeons use a method called decompression surgery whereby a piece of bone is removed from the spinal cord to relieve the pressure - but there is a risk that the tension will build up again causing the same problem in future. At the Filum System clinic, Spanish doctors say their minimally invasive technique allows them ‘eliminate the root cause and stop further progression of the condition’.  But the costly procedure will set back Allesha £, who has now set up a GoFundMe to cover the procedure and medical expenses.Allesha said: “I suffer with crippling back pain and neck pain, sickness and fatigue. “Before this started I was about to start volunteering in a law firm and I was at college but I had to quit. “From the very beginning I have been dealing with this by myself. “To get this surgery and have my le back would mean everything, I just want to be alive.”The NHS was approached for comment.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSBack painTeenagersPeople" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tributes beautiful woman 25 who
story: Beautul woman, , died after taking illegal slimming pills containing toxic chemicalAnnie Gresham, , was found on a bridge overlooking the A by ambulance crews after taking a highly toxic chemical which is illegally sold as a dieting pillAnnie Gresham, , had a history of mental illness before her death last year Image: BPM MEDIAByAntony Thrower:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A woman who died after taking illegal diet pills has been praised as intelligent, beautul and caring in loving tributes from her heartbroken family. Annie Gresham, , had a history of mental illness and was diagnosed with anorexia and emotionally unstable personality disorder . In November, she took a highly toxic chemical which is illegally sold as a weight-reduction product despite being not licensed for humans. An inquest at Derby Coroner’s Court was told Annie was found in her pyjamas on a bridge overlooking the A where she told ambulance crews to leave her as she was dying anyway. She later told staff she had taken an overdose of the drug and, despite the work of medics at the hospital, she died the same night. In a statement her family accused the system of failing their daughter. They said: Annie Greshamwas a much loved daughter, sister, auntie and friend. She was intelligent, caring, beautul, and had an amazing sense of humour. We miss her every day.  We would like to express our sincere thanks to the police, ambulance service and staff at the Royal Derby Accident and Emergency department. We had frequent contact with all three organisations, and their professionalism, care and compassion have been amazing throughout. We cannot thank them enough. Annie received compassionate care from many iniduals in the mental health sector over the years and for this we are truly grateful. What we would like to happen is for the iniduals who worked with Annie to examine their decisions and actions, and question whether with hindsight, they would do things dferently. Then to remember this next time, for the next patient and their family. In addition we hope that professionals and people in a position of power will challenge the level of care for mental health in this country. In our opinion the system failed Annie and will continue to fail others unless there is a drastic change. Peter Nieto, area coroner for Derby and Derbyshire, recorded a narrative conclusion as there was no indication Annie had planned to take her own le. He said: “It was clear she had consciously taken the tablets on  November. That canapost have occurred accidentally. But she must have known that there was a high likelihood that she would have been seen and therefore she would likely have then been taken to hospital, where she would have received some treatment. Had she taken herself somewhere private, then I think the case would be dferent.” A note was found after Annie died but the coroner said it did not contain any suicidal content - although it could be interpreted as a farewell note. Mr Nieto added: “I hope the inquest has been of some help in some way and I give my condolences to you for Annieaposs death at such a young age.
