title: stoppages no excuse brentford defeat   ivan toney
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThere were bizarre scenes at Brentford’s Community Stadium as both sets of players were forced off the pitch for almost  minutes while a drone hovered above.The flying nuisance eventually buzzed off to allow play to get back under way, and Joao Moutinho put Wolves ahead before Toney equalised.But Ruben Neves brought the Bees crashing back down to earth as his late strike condemned them to a - loss, their sixth defeat in seven matches.“It was a tough one to take,” said Toney. “I felt that when we got the equaliser it was only going to go one way, which was our way.“But obviously the quality they showed from the edge of the box, they’ve got the quality to do that.“It was tough but we can’t use it as an excuse. Both teams had the stoppage. Obviously you’ve got to stay focused and keep on the move.“I felt that when we came back out from the pause for the drone we started sloppy. But it’s stops and starts and we can’t do anything about that.“You’ve got to go out and continue with the game and they coped with it well and got the three points.”Toney’s goal, a fine volley from Bryan Mbeumo’s free-kick, took his tally for the season to seven.The -year-old feels Brentford need to use the international break to “reset” and get back to winning ways before they get sucked into trouble.“I feel there’s something we can take out of the game, we have to look forward now and try to change it in the next game,” he added.“On a personal note it was another one for the tally but it’s much sweeter when there’s three points behind it.“It’s time to reset. Obviously we’re on a bad run, we know that. But it’s not like we’ve been playing badly, we’re just conceding silly goals.“If we cut that out we’ve got a great chance. It’s time to restart and go again.”Wolves winger Adama Traore came on as a substitute amid reports linking him with Tottenham, and had a late goal ruled out for a tight offside..remove“The most important thing is the way he plays for us,” said boss Bruno Lage.“He played again with energy and scored the third ‘goal’ again. He scored last week, and the way he celebrated with his team-mates and also with me.“He’s a team player, a big professional and a lovely guy. I’m very happy with him.”.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Stoppages were no excuse for Brentford defeat  u Ivan Toney article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: thomas pieters hopes abu dhabi win inspires emerging belgians
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPieters, who turns  next week, finished one shot clear of Spaniard Rafa Cabrera Bello and - outsider Shubhankar Sharma, to take his sixth DP World Tour triumph and the £million winner’s prize.Frenchman Victor Dubuisson took a tie for fourth alongside Viktor Hovland, while defending champion Tyrrell Hatton recorded an eagle and four birdies to finish three shots back in sixth place with countrymen Ian Poulter and James Morrison..@Thomas_Pieters wins the Abu Dhabi HSBC Championship 🏆 #ADGolfChamps | #RolexSeries pic ETHNHrDroM— DP World TourJanuary , Scotland’s Scott Jamieson, who held the overnight lead, carded a disappointing five-over  to finish four off the lead in th.“I’m happy I can finally get my caddy, Adam a gold bib [for winning a Rolex Series event],” said Pieters, who finished with a final-round .“I chickened out on the last. I was gong to go for it but I was told I was two ahead so I decided to lay up and I made a [par] five which was fine.“I just hope all the juniors back in Belgium are watching this. I used to think it was impossible, but when Nico [Colsaerts] came on the scene and started winning that was inspiring and I hope that is the same for the kids back home.”Rory McIlroy will be pondering what might have been after he moved to within two of the lead, courtesy of a superb -yard eagle on the par-four ninth and a birdie on .Rory McIlroy hole-out eagle!#ADGolfChamps | #RolexSeries pic fvOLsbpJmY— DP World TourJanuary , But his round fell apart with three bogeys in the final five holes – the Ulsterman eventually ending the week with a three-under  in a tie for th.“Honestly, I am just happy that I got to play an extra two days,” said McIlroy..remove“I had to make a birdie on the last hole on Friday night just to be here, and I almost made the most of the weekend.“I played well yesterday, and really well today through , and then a couple of loose shots coming in cost me.“It wasn’t the finish I wanted, but big-picture wise it was good to play another  holes and assess where everything is and know what to work on.” vw,vw,px, px"Scott Jamieson endured a disappointing final round in Abu Dhabi Jamieson led after every round at Yas Links, setting the pace with a brilliant opening  and staying ahead with a  before heading into the final round with a one-shot advantage over Pieters after a .But the -year-old, whose sole World Tour sole triumph came nine years ago over  weather-affected holes and a modied layout at the Nelson Mandela Championship, was unable to recover from a poor start, which included four bogeys in the first five holes.Former Open champion Shane Lowry was one shot behind Jamieson following Saturday’s play, but he too endured a final round to forget which started with a triple-bogey seven on the opening hole. title: co armagh mum of three hilary singleton delighted at obe for services to the ni community sector
story: Manwho was in in possession of heroin receives suspended jail sentence   Shooting at Portadown home of elderly woman is ‘deplorable’NewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleCo Armagh mum of three Hilary Singleton ‘delighted’ at OBE for services to the NI community sectorWith a long track record in public and community service, Hilary Singleton is ‘delighted’ that she was named in the Queen’s New Year’s Honours list for an OBE.By Carmel RobinsonSaturday, nd January , : am  "       "  The honour is for services to the community sector.Formerly from Coleraine and now living in Mullaghbrack near Markethill, Co Armagh, Hilary is a Board member of the International Fund for Ireland.Hilary grew up on the north coast, attended Coleraine High School and then studied Law at Queen’s University, Belfast, qualying as a solicitor in . She spent her legal career in private practice.Hilary Singleton OBE, originally from Coleraine and now living in Mullaghbrack, near Markethill, Co Armagh. Mrs Singleton was honoured with an OBE for services to the Community Sector in the Queens New Years Honours List.In , she was appointed by the Secretary of State for NI to the International Fund for Ireland, where she currently serves as a Board member. During her time with the IFI she influenced the development of innovative programmes and initiatives aimed at tackling some of the most dficult community issues within marginalised communities in NI and the border counties of Ireland.‘I am delighted at receiving this award which recognises the vital work in marginalised communities undertaken by the International Fund for Ireland. The award is a great honour and a wonderful way to start ’. It will be presented at Buckingham Palace on a date yet to be confirmed.Hilary currently also serves as a member of the Local Government Staff Commission and, last year, was appointed to the Board of the NI Fire and Rescue Service. She is a former Deputy Chair of the Health and Safety Executive of NI and a former Board member of the Ulster-Scots Agency, where she chaired the Agency’s Education and Audit and Risk Committees.In , she became Chair of the Southern Zone Steering Group of the Social Investment Fund whose Strategic Area Plan for the Zone addressed key issues of social and economic deprivation and employability and brought signicant investment from the NI Executive to the area.In December , she was appointed by the First and Deputy First Ministers to the Compact Civic Advisory Panel.She is a former Governor of Markethill High School and has been a Director of Mid-Armagh Community Network for many years.Hilary is married to Lewis, a solicitor, and has three children - William, Joanna and Jonathan. title: geolin takes the plunge to raise much needed funds for dog charity
story: Newtownabbey woman kicked driver on head causing police car to swerve at mph   Girl assaulted in Lurgan after being chased and grabbed by womanNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleGeolin takes the plunge to raise much needed funds for dog charityLisburn woman Geolin Walsh is braving the icy waters and taking the plunge to raise money for Lucy’s Trust, an animal charity close to her heart,By Julie-Ann SpenceSunday, rd January , : am  "       "  Geolin Walsh takes the plunge for charityGeolin only recently started open water swimming but has loved it so much that she decided to use her new found passion to fund one of her other passions, animal welfare, by supporting the local charity Lucy’s Trust.“I attended a natural resilience course last March, run by a guy called Ciaran May,” explained Geolin. “Part of this course was a cold water emersion in the sea, amongst other scary stuff.“I very nearly let that put me off, as i wasn’t a great swimmer, hadn’t swam in many year in a pool let alone the sea, and I had a fear of open water. I am not very body confident and the thought of putting on a swim suit horried me, and getting changed afterwards as well.”One of the dogs being looked after by Lucys TrustHowever, despite her fears, Geolin decided to be brave and take the plunge. “I wanted to challenge myself and thoughtI was going too do it I wanted to do it properly and learn how too swim in the sea,” she continued. “I looked for an open water swimming coach and Colin Mccard came very highly recommended.“I had my first lesson last April. It was freezing, I got cramp, I was terried, but, I loved it and have been taking open sea swimming lessons ever since. It took weeks too overcome my fears of being out of my depth, and actually learning how to swim, especially putting my face in the water, but it was all possible with the patience of a fantastic coach Colin. I feel ready to swim a distance and hopefully raise as much money as I can for the charity I volunteer at Lucy’s Trust.”Run by Olivia Kenned, who is a veterinary surgeon, and her partner Rob Durston, Lucy’s Trust, which is based near Lisburn, is a sanctuary for dogs who cannot be rehomed due to behavioural issues, or those that are in most need of a rescue place, and or assistance to overcome their dficulties to become happy healthy dogs once again.“This past two years has seen a signicant rise in the number of dogs Lucy’s Trust have been asked to take in with behavioural problems,” explained Geolin. “I am deeply saddened in the knowledge that many of these dogs are being put to sleep, young healthy dogs, who with the right commitment and guidance from their s could have gone on to live happy lives. This is not the fault of our struggling animal rescues, who can only take in the numbers they can actively care for.“Every rescue that I know of has been inundated with dogs in the last year. The current developing situation can only be referred to as a crisis. As a country we are failing our dogs on an unprecedented level, and I are really urging the general public to step up and take responsibility for the dog which they chose to procure. Please contact Lucy’s Trust for behavioural advice and recommendations for local positive reinforcement trainers who will help you to help your dog. Giving them up is not the answer, it is not a solution,”To help Lucy’s Trust continue their work, Geolin is planning to swim m- metres at Helen’s Bay. If you would like to support Geolin’s fundraising effort, visit https:gofund.me efd

title: call for historic pension underpayments to be resolved
story: Larne painter alleged to have ‘approached houses’ after being released on bail   ‘Substantial’ sum of money found in PortadownNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsCall for historic pension underpayments to be resolvedSouth Tyrone Ulster Unionist MLA Rosemary Barton has said that the Department of Works  Pensions should inject urgency into resolving the underpayment to pensioners that had gone on for years.By Stanley CampbellSunday, rd January , : am  "       "  Mrs Barton said: “The DWP estimates it has underpaid , pensioners, mostly women, over £bn of their state pension entitlement, with some errors dating as far back as .“The long-term underpayment of state pensioners, an unknown number of whom will have died without receiving what they were owed, is disgraceful and requires urgent resolution.“Many people who were owed money from this process have since died, there doesn’t appear to be any provision as to how to deal with this situation for the families of loved ones that have passed away and were underpaid.”Rosemary Barton MLA.The Department for Work and Pensions are identying customers who have been underpaid State Pension in accordance with the law.If DWP identy you have been underpaid, they will let you know of the changes to your State Pension and any arrears due. title: take part in this year s big garden birdwatch
story: Keep your eyes wide open, get the kettle on and grab your binoculars as RSPB NI encourage you to join in on the charity’s Big Garden Birdwatch this month. That’s right, registration is now open for the world’s largest garden wildle survey taking place th- th January , and you don’t even have to leave your home to be part of it. RSPB NI is asking the public of Northern Ireland to spend just one hour watching and recording the birds in their garden, balcony or local park, then send their results to the RSPB. Over a million people took part in , counting  million birds – making it the biggest Birdwatch ever! By taking part in the Birdwatch, you will be helping to build an annual snapshot of how birdle is doing across the UK. It is only by understanding how wildle is faring that we can protect it. So, what are you waiting for  Take action to help solve the problems facing nature! To take part in the Big Garden Birdwatch  and receive your FREE Big Garden Birdwatch guide, which includes a bird identication chart, top tips for your birdwatch, plus advice on how to help you
